masterFinding.verificationInstructions:
Verification Instructions

Look for client side input validation (usually JavaScript) or disabled functionality (grayed out buttons or form fields). If actual attacks, such as XSS, can be exploited, then report those. Use this finding if bad user input causes functional problems. For example, if adding invalid parameter values to user input breaks some application functionality.

Reporting Requirements
  1. Describe implemented client-side controls

  2. Show the initial page

  3. Show request with invalid input

  4. Show broken functionality

  5. Add an explanation whether the issue affects only the current user or other users as well
masterFinding.remediationInstructions: Use client-side input validation and control only as a redundant form of input validation. Implement server-side input validation and controls that ensure any data received from users will be subject to validation even if the user disables any client-side controls.
masterFinding.name: Insufficient Input Validation - Client-Side Controls
masterFinding.businessImpact: Insufficient input validation allows unexpected user input to be submitted to the application. This may modify the application behavior or render some portions of the application unusable.
masterFinding.description: The application uses client-side input validation to ensure that the client inputs proper data to form fields. A malicious user can bypass the client-side controls and submit unexpected data to the application.
